messageBody:
Hi,
 
I would like some advice on how to organize tests. I seem to find myself facing many instances of the following pattern:
 
I have some sort of service I would like to test. I would like to test a variety of features of the service: we could call them A, B, C, D and E. Now the service can be configured to operate in various modes.
 
For example, I have a service involving messaging using TCP/IP connections. It can run using either plain, raw TCP connections, or alternatively it should work with SSL as well. Virtually all of the code doesn't care which mode it is in (in other words, this distinction is transparent to my code). So of course I simply want to write one set of tests to verify the correct operation of features A, B, C, D and E.
 
It's even tempting not to bother with running all the tests using both modes. But to be thorough I want to do so.
 
Now an organization that seems natural to me is something like this:
 
class TcpTests extends TestCase {
    public void setUp() throws Exception {
        tcpService = new TcpService();
        boolean useSSL = something;  // ??
        tcpService.setUseSSL(useSSL);
        tcpService.start();
    }
    public void testA() throws Exception { ... }
    public void testB() throws Exception { ... }
    ....
    public void testE() throws Exception { ... }
    public void tearDown() throws Exception {
        tcpService.stop();
    }
}
 
How do I run this set of tests in both modes (first with plain connections, say, and then with SSL connections)?
 
Is my problem that I have put the wrong sort of thing in the setUp() method?
 
Another way that came to mind was to ignore the setUp() and tearDown() routines, and do something like the following:
 
class TcpTests extends TestCase {
    public void testWithoutSSL() {
        initTcp(false);
        doASeries();
    }
    public void testWithSSL() {
        initTcp(true);
        doASeries();
    }
    private void initTcp(boolean useSSL) {
        // as in setUp() of first example
    }
    private void doASeries() {
        doFeatureA();
        doFeatureB();
        ...
        doFeatureE();
    }
}
 
Besides being somehow aesthetically not pleasing, this means that from JUnit's point of view I have only two tests. I feel I should have ten. I guess, also, that if a particular feature fails, then all the other features that were to be tested after it will not even get tried. That's obviously not right.
 
Then the other thing I thought was, would this be an appropriate occasion to use a hierarchy of TestCase classes? In other words, maybe I go back to the first pattern (above), but make it an abstract class. Define an abstract method, called perhaps something like getSSLSetting(). Have setUp() call this method to determine what the setting should be. Now I create two (concrete) subclasses, one for each possible setting of the useSSL flag that I want to test. In the subclasses, the only method I have to define is getSSLSetting(). JUnit sees two different TestCase classes (I have to put two different classes into my TestSuite: the concrete classes only, of course, not the abstract super-class.) Each of the two has 5 tests, for a total of 10.
 
I guess, generalizing this (assuming I have a more complex set of configuration options), I could create any number of subclasses representing specific combinations of configuration settings that I want to test.
 
Does this seem right? I mean, is this an appropriate use of inherritance?
 
Thanks for any advice you can provide.
 
 - Alan Bram
